column101: We started Backyard Brains, a neuroscience teaching startup, at the NS&B course in 2010.  Jim Knierim graciously allowed my co-founder to attend the leach section of the course.  We developed the SpikerBox in the break room and the Kidd.  Our first commercial was filmed on location.The neuroethological approach of the NS&B course has heavily influenced our experiments and preps we use.  And we have been worked the data-blitz approach into our student intern projects.  We have returned to MBL every year since the NS&B course to teach hands-on electrophysiology to the Methods in Computational Neuroscience and the now-defunct Neuroinformatics courses using our SpikerBox.  Our goal is to one day return to the NS&B course to help teach our DIY methods.

column63: Field biologists could benefit from the perspectives and approaches that are the focus of NS&B, but field biologists seem to be poorly represented in the course. These biologists routinely make observations of animal behavior in the wild and interpret them in relation to evolutionary processes. Many then jump directly to genetic-level analyses, often completely ignoring organismal level features. These students would be a good addition to the course: they often are already familiar with genetic approaches, they appreciate behavior, and they stand to benefit the most from learning the neuroscience and physiology in the course.The course could include more computational approaches. In the same way that a parallel molecular track has been implemented, a parallel computational track might improve what is a weakness in organismal biology.

column62: 1) Each module happens too quickly. 2 weeks is not enough time to sufficiently learn a new technique or approach and to then apply it in a real experiment. The students were so overworked that there wasn't enough time for synthesis of the material they were learning. If the course was intended to be a crash course in mere exposure to techniques, then that was achieved in spades. However, if the goal was to have students think critically about using new approaches and to learn how to ask research questions from new perspectives... they simply didn't have enough time.2) For the behavioral aspect of the molecular module, there weren't suitable facilities for running animals in various behavioral paradigms. Birds were housed in a tent!3) The lectures were disorganized. Allowing the faculty to give two lectures on topics of their choice may be easier on the faculty, but probably doesn't provide a logical flow for the students.
column63: I think NS&B would benefit from having fewer cycles, and making the cycles a bit longer. Alternatively, students could quickly learn all of the potential research techniques that are available to them over the course of one month (bootcamp style), and then pick one and spend the second month conducting a real experiment. This would allow students to obtain a substantial grasp on a new approach/technique/model system and to even generate solid data for potential publications. However, restructuring the course in such a manner would make it tricky with juggling when faculty need to be present and for how long. Of course, there are pros and cons to every option.Regardless, I think the course needs to be restructured in some way so that students don't walk away in a dazed stupor, but instead can walk away from the course having truly learned something they can use in the future, having produced something of substance, and/or having experienced something that can guide their future decisions as a researcher. I think this was accomplished with some students, but I think it's also possible to restructure the course in a way that can benefit more students.

He was extremely pleased. I don't know how similar these two courses are so my knowledge I believe is out of date. Just to throw some ideas out there: imaging (e.g. super resolution techniques / live-imaging in neuronal cultures (photoactivation or bleaching) / two-photon in vivo imaging in mice) has really changed since the past 15 years when I took the course. Whole cell patch clamping in vivo in mice also is not unusual any more. Such technical advances should be reflected in the course content.

column101: I am not sure how I got on this mailing, but I thought I answer a few questions.     I took the Invertebrate Zoology Course in 1951 between junior and senior years at Yale. The course was given in the second half of the summer. During the first half I worked for John P. ‰ÛÏTrink‰Û Trinkaus on Fundulus development. I was an undergraduate assistant in his lab at Yale during the academic year. The summer of 1952 I took the Physiology Course. Both courses were inspirational. In the Invert Course we learned a lot of anatomy and taxonomy of local fauna. Converting the Invert Course to Neural Systems was a very good idea.      I returned to Woods Hole the summer of 1957 having completed a doctorate in Physiology and begun working the laboratory of Harry Grundfest, a long time summer investigator. Harry was the organizer and ran the lecture series on electrobiology fondly known as the Monday night fights. This series was ultimately taken over by the Neurobiology course.     I have been coming to the lab every summer since 1957 (and, as an aside, have run every Falmouth Road Race). I believe it was 1969 when then Director H. Burr Steinbach invited me to be on the Education Committee, probably with the reasonable charge of organizing a neurobiology course. As a product of two courses in the standard MBL mode of modules, a Neurobiology Course on the model seemed a reasonable project to me, and to lessen the burden I asked John Dowling to join me as Co-Director. There had been postdoctoral neurophysiology programs under Steve Kuffler and also Cole and Moore, but these were of a different format; generally, the students spent the entire summer working on a single project.     On at least one occasion I lectured in the Neural Systems Course. The subject was likely to have been electric fishes, electroreception or electrical synapses. It was just after the great Coffee Causes Pancreatic Cancer scare. As I recall the statistical analysis had just been shown to be faulty. I had switched to tea during the scare, and during the break in the two hour lecture, I thought I might just as well shift back to coffee. As a result my mood was significantly elevated during the second hour. Although tea is supposed to contain almost as much caffeine as coffee, during the off period I had lost my tolerance to caffeine.     On other occasions I have done such things as help the students find electric organs in gymnotid fishes. I also participate in the Wednesday night seminars, mostly to have the lights turned down so they don‰Ûªt get into the eyes of the people up front (like me).
